update.description:
Work in progress for the entity tree UI populated using the `EntityComponentManager`.

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1432105045-tree_1.png)
**New dependency**: `sudo apt install qml-module-qtqml-models2`

## Summary

* Created new type of plugin, `ignition::gazebo::GuiSystem`, which can use the ECM like `ignition::gazebo::System`s do.
* Pure ign-gui plugins inheriting from `ignition::gui::Plugin` are still supported.
* Install GUI plugins in a different path because ign-gui crawls that path to populate the plugin menu

## TODO

In the future:

* Implement the rest of @{5b6a0f313df2033d0d9a151a} 's design \(instead of the default Windows XPish look\)
* Send updates the other way around \(GUI -> Server\)
update.title: [Blueprint] Entity tree UI

content.raw:
@nkoenig @iche033 , e34f02e fixes the issue deserializing components created at runtime.

---

Component registration happens at static initialization. Only components whose headers are included in the currently loaded libraries are initialized. Some of our components, such as `JointVelocityCmd` and `BatterySoC` happened not to be included by any of the files running in the GUI, so they were not being registered and that process didn't know how to deserialize them.

That commit does several things:

* Accepts the environment variable `IGN_DEBUG_COMPONENT_FACTORY` for printing the components that are registered. This should help debugging in the future. Since components are created before `main`, we can't use ign-common's Console.
* Add a `Factory::HasType` to check types that are registered
* Use `HasType` before trying to serialize and print a warning accordingly. The warning is only printed once per component type.
* Add the meta header `components.hh`, which includes all the headers in that directory.
* Include `components.hh` in `GuiRunner.hh`, so the GUI has full support for all Gazebo components. This will be handy for the property tree.
* If you're curious enable the factory debug and compare the list of components printed for the server and GUI.
content.html:
@nkoenig @iche033 , e34f02e fixes the issue deserializing components created at runtime.

Component registration happens at static initialization. Only components whose headers are included in the currently loaded libraries are initialized. Some of our components, such as JointVelocityCmd and BatterySoC happened not to be included by any of the files running in the GUI, so they were not being registered and that process didn't know how to deserialize them.

That commit does several things:

  • Accepts the environment variable IGN_DEBUG_COMPONENT_FACTORY for printing the components that are registered. This should help debugging in the future. Since components are created before main, we can't use ign-common's Console.
  • Add a Factory::HasType to check types that are registered
  • Use HasType before trying to serialize and print a warning accordingly. The warning is only printed once per component type.
  • Add the meta header components.hh, which includes all the headers in that directory.
  • Include components.hh in GuiRunner.hh, so the GUI has full support for all Gazebo components. This will be handy for the property tree.
  • If you're curious enable the factory debug and compare the list of components printed for the server and GUI.

content.raw:
Yeah, all the plugins. I don't think the title of a card is suppose to be raised. 

Here is what cards looks like in material on angular:

https://material.angular.io/components/card/examples

The title is at the same elevation as the content.

Here is a  whole section on elevation:
https://material.io/design/environment/elevation.html#elevation-in-material-design

Having a drop shadow on the main window title bar and also the plugins looks odd, at least to me.
content.html:

Here is what cards looks like in material on angular:

https://material.angular.io/components/card/examples

The title is at the same elevation as the content.

Here is a whole section on elevation: https://material.io/design/environment/elevation.html#elevation-in-material-design

Having a drop shadow on the main window title bar and also the plugins looks odd, at least to me.

content.raw: [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/207/stop-mouse-wheel-propagation-at-the-card/diff](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/207/stop-mouse-wheel-propagation-at-the-card/diff)
content.html: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/207/stop-mouse-wheel-propagation-at-the-card/diff

content.raw:
I think we could create a `TreeItem` class that inherits from `QStandartItem` and use that in the tree. Then make `entity`, `entityName` and `type` properties of the item, and as long as they have `READ`, `WRITE` and `NOTIFY`, they _should_ be reachable from the QML. 

In the end, the QML is the one with all the info to render the items, so if we want custom renderers we'll need to change things there too. At this point, I'm not sure what this could buy us here.

Note that the entity tree will not hold the properties (i.e. components), so its purpose is a bit different from RViz's properties. We'll have a separate plugin for that, and in that case, I do think we'll need to specialize for each component type.

Does this all make sense?
content.html:
I think we could create a TreeItem class that inherits from QStandartItem and use that in the tree. Then make entity, entityName and type properties of the item, and as long as they have READ, WRITE and NOTIFY, they should be reachable from the QML.

In the end, the QML is the one with all the info to render the items, so if we want custom renderers we'll need to change things there too. At this point, I'm not sure what this could buy us here.

Note that the entity tree will not hold the properties (i.e. components), so its purpose is a bit different from RViz's properties. We'll have a separate plugin for that, and in that case, I do think we'll need to specialize for each component type.

Does this all make sense?

content.raw: Thanks for pointing it out. We should be preventing those mouse events from bubbling
content.html: Thanks for pointing it out. We should be preventing those mouse events from bubbling

content.raw:
Ah didn't think about QML, I'm not as familiar with that.  I know that RViz uses a `PropertyTree`, where everything in the tree inherits from a `Property` QObject: [https://github.com/ros2/rviz/blob/ros2/rviz\_common/include/rviz\_common/properties/property.hpp](https://github.com/ros2/rviz/blob/ros2/rviz_common/include/rviz_common/properties/property.hpp)

This enables the properties to be able to customize their appearances and control schemes.

Not critical here, but could be an interesting enhancement down the road.
content.html:
Ah didn't think about QML, I'm not as familiar with that. I know that RViz uses a PropertyTree, where everything in the tree inherits from a Property QObject: https://github.com/ros2/rviz/blob/ros2/rviz_common/include/rviz_common/properties/property.hpp

This enables the properties to be able to customize their appearances and control schemes.

Not critical here, but could be an interesting enhancement down the road.

content.raw: This actually seems to be true with other widgets, so it may not be an error specific to this.
content.html: This actually seems to be true with other widgets, so it may not be an error specific to this.

content.raw: humm that's an interesting idea. I'd have to check how that would tie into the QML.
content.html: humm that's an interesting idea. I'd have to check how that would tie into the QML.

content.raw:
I noticed that the EntityTree Window doesn’t seem to capture the scroll wheel when it’s undocked and will also zoom the display.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Open a world
2. Open the EntityTree Widget
3. Undock the widget
4. Resize until it has a scroll bar
5. Scroll in the widget

The EntityTree will scroll and the GUI will zoom.
content.html:
I noticed that the EntityTree Window doesn’t seem to capture the scroll wheel when it’s undocked and will also zoom the display.

Steps to reproduce:

  1. Open a world
  2. Open the EntityTree Widget
  3. Undock the widget
  4. Resize until it has a scroll bar
  5. Scroll in the widget

The EntityTree will scroll and the GUI will zoom.
